Award.AwardTitle: An Empirical Examination of the Evolution of Innovation

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will study how gradual mutation accumulation can bring about sudden and dramatic changes to a simple genetic system. We are studying a ribonucleic acid (RNA) that can propagate genetically, but which also is able to act as an RNA enzyme, to chemically convert (cut or splice) other RNA fragments. The form that is most active in RNA cutting and the form that is most active in RNA splicing are genetically and chemically similar; they are separated by less than 20 mutations. We will study the biochemical properties of all the intermediary forms to see how activity of an RNA enzyme changes into its opposite. In some of the non-scientific critique of the evolutionary concepts, the very existence of such sudden changes in evolution have been cast into doubt, and we expect that the dissemination of the results of this research will help facilitate a discussion of how scientific experiments can address difficult questions in evolutionary biology. This research will bring together a graduate trainee in biomolecular sciences and a computational biologist, and these researchers will also participate in this univeristy's programs that are aimed at broadening the participation of groups underrepresented in science, mathematics, engineering and technology.

The activities of this research will reconstruct and evaluate the evolutionary pathways between two RNA molecules with two distinct structures and functions. RNA molecules are chosen because they allow analysis of both mutational changes and their functional consequences in high-throughput using modern sequencing technology. About one million intermediate forms between these two starting molecules will be constructed in the lab. Each of these intermediate sequences will be tested for their ability to perform each of the two functions. The results will be used to construct two ?fitness landscapes? that overlap. All possible pathways between peaks within and between the two landscapes will be explored computationally to predict how evolution could be aided or hindered by the structure of these landscapes, and to determine under what scenarios this type of evolutionary innovation is possible.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

A long-standing debate in biology is whether evolution proceeds primarily by gradual changes or by bursts of phenotypic innovations. Numerous examples of gradual changes have been produced through experimental evolution. However, experimental reproductions of punctuated changes are lacking, preventing an empirical comparison of the two processes. This research project produced an experimental model of the transition between two distinct molecular functions and investigated the challenge of evolving from one function to the other. To do this, the project used enzymes made of RNA that catalyze two different biochemical reactions. A high-throughput approach was developed to study both the sequence and the function simultaneously, which was enabled by the choice of RNA enzymes, as to the more commonly studied protein enzymes. Thousands of genetic changes to the two enzymes were synthesized and the high-throughput approach was used to determine the effect of thousands of combinations of mutations. The resulting data was used to map genetic change to each enzyme function, creating what is referred to as “fitness landscapes”. In this project, the fitness landscapes actually overlapped, and numerous genetic sequences could carry out both enzyme functions, to some extent. This was surprising because only a single example of thus dual-function enzyme was known prior to this project. To understand the evolutionary implications, computational software was developed that simulated thousands of individual RNA molecules competing for survival, using the fitness landscape data to drive the probability of survival. The dynamics of our simulation showed periods of stasis followed by sudden bursts of adaptation. This is interesting because this dynamic is similar to what has been observed in the fossil record at geological time scales. The results of this project provided a new glimpse at evolutionary innovation at the molecular level and suggest that organismal evolutionary dynamics may be explainable by the underlying fitness landscapes of macromolecules like RNA and protein.

 

Broader Impacts

This project helped develop scientists that are ready for the data revolution. The undergraduate and graduate student participants of this project received training in computational skills required to handle the high-throughput DNA sequencing data that was used. The students’ level of achievement is evident in the new software that has been developed, which will hopefully be useful to others interested in predicting evolutionary dynamics. The students on the project also participated in a campus wide effort to create a culture where computing training was inclusive and supportive. Along those lines, a new model of integrative teaching and research was developed, called a vertically integrated project, or VIP. This VIP allows students to get credit for research activity, while they moved from beginning researcher to mentoring roles. The students were recruited from multiple disciplines and majors across campus and graduate students provided research objectives. The VIP course is growing in popularity and looks poised to keep training students on scientific computing skills into the foreseeable future. Additionally, several outreach activities were conducted in conjunction with this project. First, a biology section was developed for a summer camp for TRIO (Upward Bound) that aims to prepare first generation and/or limited income students for university. In addition, project participants put on several science cafés at local libraries for elementary and middle school students. The cafes exposed the students to biological ideas including genetic manipulations and evolution. Students were encouraged to discuss the ethics and safety of such projects. Finally, an undergraduate researcher supported by this project started a biology club to encourage more students to get involved in research and organize outreach activities. The club has grown to over 70 members already, and looks to be sustainable into the future.
